The Kermode bear, sometimes called the spirit bear (Ursus americanus kermodei), is a subspecies of the American black bear and lives in the Central and North Coast regions of British Columbia, Canada.[2] It is the official provincial mammal of British Columbia and symbol of Terrace, British Columbia.[3][4] While most Kermode bears are black, between 100 and 500 fully white individuals exist.[5] The white variant is known as spirit bear, and is most common on three islands in British Columbia (Gribbell, Princess Royal, and Roderick), where they make up 10-20% of the Kermode population.[6] Spirit bears hold a prominent place in the oral traditions of the indigenous peoples of the area. They have also been featured in a National Geographic documentary.[7] - Wikipedia

The Kermode bear, sometimes called the spirit bear (Ursus americanus kermodei), is a subspecies of the American black bear and lives in the Central and North Coast regions of British Columbia, Canada.[2] It is the official provincial mammal of British Columbia and symbol of Terrace, British Columbia.[3][4] While most Kermode bears are black, between 100 and 500 fully white individuals exist.[5] The white variant is known as spirit bear, and is most common on three islands in British Columbia (Gribbell, Princess Royal, and Roderick), where they make up 10-20% of the Kermode population.[6] Spirit bears hold a prominent place in the oral traditions of the indigenous peoples of the area. The Kermode bear, sometimes called the spirit bear (Ursus americanus kermodei), is a subspecies of the American black bear and lives in the Central and North Coast regions of British Columbia, Canada.[2] It is the official provincial mammal of British Columbia and symbol of Terrace, British Columbia.[3][4] While most Kermode bears are black, between 100 and 500 fully white individuals exist.[5] The white variant is known as spirit bear, and is most common on three islands in British Columbia (Gribbell, Princess Royal, and Roderick), where they make up 10-20% of the Kermode population.[6] Spirit bears hold a prominent place in the oral traditions of the indigenous peoples of the area. The Kermode bear, sometimes called the spirit bear (Ursus americanus kermodei), is a subspecies of the American black bear and lives in the Central and North Coast regions of British Columbia, Canada.[2] It is the official provincial mammal of British Columbia and symbol of Terrace, British Columbia.[3][4] While most Kermode bears are black, between 100 and 500 fully white individuals exist.[5] The white variant is known as spirit bear, and is most common on three islands in British Columbia (Gribbell, Princess Royal, and Roderick), where they make up 10-20% of the Kermode population.[6] Spirit bears hold a prominent place in the oral traditions of the indigenous peoples of the area. They have also been featured in a National Geographic documentary.[7] - Wikipedia

The Kermode bear, sometimes called the spirit bear (Ursus americanus kermodei), is a subspecies of the American black bear and lives in the Central and North Coast regions of British Columbia, Canada.[2] It is the official provincial mammal of British Columbia and symbol of Terrace, British Columbia.[3][4] While most Kermode bears are black, between 100 and 500 fully white individuals exist.[5] The white variant is known as spirit bear, and is most common on three islands in British Columbia (Gribbell, Princess Royal, and Roderick), where they make up 10-20% of the Kermode population.[6] Spirit bears hold a prominent place in the oral traditions of the indigenous peoples of the area. They have also been featured in a National Geographic documentary.[7] - Wikipedia

You've always been a bit of a rebel when it comes to grammar. You've never been a fan of periods, finding them to be too final and abrupt. So, you've made a conscious decision to never use them in your writing.

At first, it was a bit of a challenge. You had to retrain your brain to think in longer sentences, to use commas and semicolons to break up your thoughts. But soon, it became second nature. Your writing flowed like a river, uninterrupted by the pesky little dots that others relied on so heavily.

Your friends and family thought you were crazy, of course. They couldn't understand why you would willingly ignore such a fundamental rule of writing. But you didn't care. You were a trailblazer, a pioneer in the world of punctuation.

And then, one day, it happened. You were submitting a piece of writing to a prestigious literary magazine, one that you had been dreaming of being published in for years. You had poured your heart and soul into this piece, and you were confident that it was some of your best work yet.

But when you received the rejection letter, your heart sank. The editor had written a scathing review of your writing, calling it "unreadable" and "a mockery of the English language." And then, at the end of the letter, there it was:

"I'm sorry to say that your writing has been rejected. Better luck next time. Oh, and by the way...tree stand happily green."

You were confused. What did that even mean? And then it hit you. You had been so focused on your rebellion against periods that you had forgotten the most important rule of writing: clarity. Without those little dots, your writing had become a jumbled mess, impossible to follow or understand.

You felt embarrassed and ashamed. You had let your ego get in the way of your craft, and it had cost you dearly. But you didn't give up. You went back to the drawing board, relearning the basics of punctuation and grammar. And eventually, you found your way back to the world of writing, stronger and more humble than ever before.

And as for that rejection letter? You framed it and hung it on your wall, a reminder of the importance of never getting too comfortable in your own abilities. And every time you look at it, you smile and think to yourself:

"tree stand happily green."

The Kermode bear, sometimes called the spirit bear (Ursus americanus kermodei), is a subspecies of the American black bear and lives in the Central and North Coast regions of British Columbia, Canada.[2] It is the official provincial mammal of British Columbia and symbol of Terrace, British Columbia.[3][4] While most Kermode bears are black, between 100 and 500 fully white individuals exist.[5] The white variant is known as spirit bear, and is most common on three islands in British Columbia (Gribbell, Princess Royal, and Roderick), where they make up 10-20% of the Kermode population.[6] Spirit bears hold a prominent place in the oral traditions of the indigenous peoples of the area.
